Graphical abstract Metal-nitrogen series batteries encompass aqueous/organic metal-N2, aqueous metal-NO x , and aqueous metal-NO x – batteries. These systems hold promise for simultaneous electricity generation, valuable ammonia synthesis, wastewater treatment, and gas decontamination. Ammonia plays a crucial role in contemporary society, impacting medicine, agriculture, and the chemical industry. The conventional industrial synthesis of NH3 through the Haber-Bosch technique, carried out under severe reaction conditions, leads to substantial energy consumption and environmental pollution. It is thus imperative for NH3 synthesis methods to be investigated under more favorable conditions. Synthesis of ammonia by electrocatalysis can effectively reduce the environmental damage and other urgent problems, which is a promising solution. Metal-nitrogen series batteries (M−N batteries), such as metal-nitrogen gas batteries, metal-nitrogen oxide batteries and metal-oxynitride batteries have been regarded recently as an exemplar of concurrent NH3 synthesis and energy production.Nonetheless, the large-scale application of these batteries is still limited by numerous challenges are currently existing in building high-efficiency M−N batteries, including poor Faradic efficiency and low NH3 yield. Therefore, a comprehensive overview of M−N batteries is offered, specifically focusing on advanced strategies for designing highly efficient cathode catalysts in anticipation of future developments. The metal anodes, cathodic electro-reduction reactions, and design principles are encompassed in the discussion, offering detailed insights to enhance understanding. Mechanisms, feasibility analyses, technoeconomic assessments, device combinations, and comparative evaluations are delved into in the review, contributing to a thorough comprehension of diverse systems and their application potential. Perspectives and opportunities for future research directions are also delineated. Keywords Metal-N2 batteries Metal-NO x – batteries Energy storage Ammonia production Electrocatalysts 1 Introduction The energy crisis primarily stems from the combustion of non-renewable fossil fuels, such as coal, oil, and natural gas [1]. The massive consumption of non-renewable fossil fuels not only exacerbates the energy crisis, but also places a significant strain on the environment due to the release of carbon dioxide. Consequently, it is crucial to underscore the imperative of reducing CO2 emissions and establishing a renewable energy framework [2–6]. Nonetheless, in spite of the promising future of renewable energy, the utilization of renewable energy is hindered by intermittency and volatility. A crucial step in realizing large-scale renewable energy utilization is the development and deployment of electrochemical energy conversion and storage technologies [7–9]. Batteries, as a typical energy storage device, can facilitate energy transfer and drive the implementation of novel energy applications [10–12]. Conventional lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are preferred for their high energy density and consistent cycling performance, making them a popular choice among users [12–14]. Despite the practical implementation of LIBs, numerous challenges persist in their functionality. One of them is that LIBs tailored exclusively for high energy density lack the capacity to seamlessly integrate with renewable energy resources and store diverse forms of energy in the form of value-added chemicals [15]. Furthermore, lithium-ion batteries necessitate circuit protection mechanisms to avert overcharging or over-discharging, and there are limitations on the conditions under which they can be employed. Hence, the focus ought to be on investigating interconnected redox reactions alongside phase alterations during discharge and charge cycles, aiming to produce valuable substances within advanced metal-redox bifunctional catalyst (bicatalyst) batteries [16–18]. Among various value-added metal-redox bicatalyst batteries, the emergence of metal-N series batteries (M−N batteries) has captured the interest of scientific researchers [19–21]. M−N batteries (Fig. 1 ), including aqueous/organic metal-N2, aqueous metal-NO, aqueous metal-NO2, aqueous metal-NO3 –, and aqueous metal-NO2 – batteries [22–24], possess the capability to convert worthless or harmful N species into NH3 while simultaneously generating energy. As the product of M−N batteries, ammonia serves essential roles not only in the manufacturing but also plays a crucial part in the field of energy conversion [25–27]. The Haber-Bosch process currently stands as the predominant approach for ammonia synthesis. However, it demands elevated temperature and pressure conditions and consumes large amounts of coal and natural gas, resulting in a huge amount of carbon dioxide being released into the environment. Hence, M−N batteries, utilizing electrochemical methods to produce ammonia, emerge as a viable alternative to energy-intensive methods and environmentally burdensome Haber-Bosch process. The introduction of M−N batteries serves a twofold objective, as this technology not only enables ammonia production without CO2 emission but also simultaneously produces electricity. Nevertheless, as a nascent energy storage technology, M−N batteries still grapple with certain technical challenges. To guarantee the efficient and consistent functioning and achieve the rechargeable procedure of M−N batteries, numerous investigations have concentrated on developing electrocatalysts with diverse catalytic capabilities suitable for bifunctional electrolysis within the context of these batteries [28–30]. Recently, considerable progress has been achieved in researching bicatalyst batteries with partial metal-redox value addition, as evidenced by a number of remarkable review articles. Researchers conducted an in-depth analysis of recent advancements in carbon-based non-precious metal catalysts within the realm of metal-gas batteries, culminating a comprehensive summary of the current state of metal-gas batteries employing carbon-based non-precious metal catalysts [31]. A comprehensive review was conducted on the research progress of metal-N2 batteries, discussing the electrochemical reaction mechanisms in diverse metal-N2 batteries, offering a critical evaluation of existing obstacles and prospective applications [32]. The foundational principles and design concepts governing rechargeable/reversible aqueous metal-redox bicatalyst batteries, encompassing an examination of how individual components influence energy conversion and chemical production within these systems, were clarified. Additionally, the research encapsulated the electrocatalytic processes of reduction/oxidation, the existing systems dependent on redox reactions, and the associated bifunctional catalysts for redox reactions [33]. Metal-N2/NO x batteries and metal-NO x – batteries exhibit disparities not only in their reaction potentials but also in the involved reaction species. Surprisingly, there is a lack of comprehensive reviews that distinctly address these variations between the two battery types. To foster a more profound comprehension of M−N batteries, we offer an extensive and in-depth review encompassing battery mechanics and cathode discharging reactions, such as nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR), nitric oxide reduction reaction (NORR), nitrate reduction reaction (NO3 –RR) and nitrite reduction reaction (NO2 –RR). We firstly conduct an extensive analysis of both the cathodes and anodes incorporated in M−N batteries. Subsequently, we explore recent advancements in electrocatalyst design within diverse M−N battery configurations. Beginning with an examination of organic/aqueous metal-gas batteries, we proceed to introduce aqueous metal-nitrate/nitrite batteries. The emphasis lies on elucidating effective strategies to enhance electrocatalyst activity, selectivity and stability, with a keen consideration of their significance in battery applications. Lastly, we outline the prevailing challenges and potential opportunities confronting current M−N bifunctional catalyst batteries, offering valuable insights for future research endeavors. This review marks the inaugural attempt to assess the present status of two distinct M−N battery systems and forecast their future developmental trajectories. 2 Overview of metal-N redox batteries In a common setup featuring a metal-redox bicatalyst battery configuration, key components include a metallic anode, a cathode with bifunctional catalytic properties, and a bipolar separator. This separator divides the electrolytes into separate sections while managing their pH levels independently. During discharge, substances such as N2 are introduced into the cathodic section, accepting electrons to produce valuable products. At the same time, the metallic anodes undergo electron loss, transforming into oxides or hydroxides. This interaction between power generation and chemical synthesis lies at the heart of its operational mechanism. Gas, typically the primary reactant, requires a flow regulator within the electrochemical apparatus, guiding its movement from an external source to the cathode surface, where the resulting chemicals are accumulated. To delineate the battery charging process, there are three distinctions among metal-redox bicatalyst batteries: (a) The non-rechargeability of primary cells, potentially stemming from irreversible reactions or design deficiencies; (b) Reversible batteries undergo a reverse reaction during discharge, wherein the product accepts electrons and returns to its initial reactant state; (c) Rechargeable batteries involve the formation of discharge products, with new substances being oxidized during charging, typically via OER with water at the anode, thereby completing the cycle [41,42]. 2.1 Considerations for anodes The metallic anode plays a pivotal role in M−N species batteries. Alkali metals like Li and Na are better suited for non-aqueous environments, as indicated by prior research [43,44], whereas Mg, Al, and Zn are frequently employed in batteries using aqueous M−N species [45–47]. Among various metal negatives, lithium metal stands out due to its exceptionally light mass (M w = 6.94 g mol−1, ρ = 0.535 g cm−3), electronegativity of −3.045 V (in comparison to the standard hydrogen electrode SHE potential), and an impressive theoretical specific capacity of 3860 mA h g−1, underscoring its high activity [48,49]. Similar to lithium, sodium is a highly reactive metal with a low ionization energy, enabling rapid combination with nitrogen during the reaction [50,51]. On the contrast, Zn offers notable benefits including enhanced safety, environmental compatibility, and cost-effectiveness. The direct use of Zn foil as an anode electrode material can provide a theoretical specific capacity of 819 mA h g−1, which is one of the largest-scale energy storage battery technologies with great application potential (Fig. 2 ) [52–54]. Within the domain of metal-based cells, Al-based batteries stand out as a highly promising energy storage alternative due to the considerable advantages of the Al anode, including high specific capacity, cost-effectiveness, abundant reserves, and lightweight composition. Al demonstrates a theoretically gravimetric capacity of 2980 mA h g−1, which is much higher than that of Mg (2200 mA h g−1) or Zn (819 mA h g−1) and only lower than that of Li. From a volume standpoint, Al has a larger volume capacity (8040 A h cm−3) than lithium (2060 A h cm−3) [55,56]. Mg is another economically viable metal choice, and when used as a metal anode, the battery has a high theoretical voltage (3.09 V) and energy density (6.8 kW h kg−1). Mg metal electrodes also have the following advantages: low electrode potential (−2.37 V vs. SHE), high Faraday capacity (2.2 A h g−1), and very low density (1.74 g cm−3) [57]. Table 1 illustrates that Li, Na, Al, and Mg exhibit higher specific capacities, whereas Zn boasts the lowest electrode potential. Among these commonly employed metal anodes, Zn predominates as the material of choice. This preference arises from the increased adaptability of chemical reactions in Zn-based batteries, facilitating a more straightforward and reversible recharge process. 2.2 Considerations for cathodes 2.2.1 Value-added reduction reactions of cathodes In the M−N species batteries, hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) takes precedence over the NRR, NORR, NO3 –RR and NO2 –RR, resulting in a poor Faradic efficiency (FE) and NH3 yield. Therefore, proper regulation of the cathode catalyst is essential. Below, we provide examples of four distinct cathode reactants engaged in Zn-N batteries within an aqueous solution. Corresponding reduction potentials at pH = 0 and their reaction mechanisms are illustrated [58–62]. N2 + 8H+ +6e– → 2NH4 +, V RHE = 0.275 V NO + 6H+ + 5e– → NH4 + + H2O, V RHE = 0.836 V NO3 – + 10H+ + 8e– → NH4 + + 3H2O, V RHE = 0.875 V NO2 – + 8H+ + 6e– → NH4 + + 2H2O, V RHE = 0.897 V By comparison, we can see that N2 has the largest negative reduction potential, while NO2 –/NO3 – has the highest electrochemical reduction potential. Consequently, NRR faces thermodynamic challenges, leading to diminished yields of NH3 and suboptimal current efficiency. Hence, NO2 –/NO3 – species present more appealing prospects for energy conversion and chemical synthesis. Drawing upon the theoretical oxidation–reduction potentials of metal anodes alongside the reduction potentials of various incremental reactions, the theoretical electromotive forces of M−N series batteries can be obtained. E theo = E cathode - E anode The theoretical energy density (ED) of these batteries is calculated as follows. ED = C × E theo where C represents the energy density attributed to the metal anodes. Additionally, we present the reaction mechanisms of four different cathode reactants used in Zn-N batteries across alkaline and neutral electrolytes. Reaction mechanisms at pH = 14 are illustrated. N2 + 8H2O + 6e– → 2NH4OH + 6OH– NO + 5H2O + 5e– → NH4OH + 5OH– NO3 – + 7H2O + 8e– → NH4OH + 9OH– NO2 – + 6H2O + 6e– → NH4OH + 7OH– Reaction mechanisms at pH = 7 are depicted. N2 + 8H2O + 6e– → 2NH4 + + 8OH– NO + 5H2O + 5e– → NH4 + + 6OH– NO3 – + 7H2O + 8e– → NH4 + + 10OH– NO2 – + 6H2O + 6e– → NH4 + + 8OH– For the battery system in which the electrolyte of Li/Na-N2 battery is an organic solution, taking the Li-N2 battery as an example, the corresponding reaction mechanism can be illustrated as follows [14]. N2 + 6Li+ + 6e– ↔ 2Li3N Li3N + 3H2O → NH3 + 3LiOH 2.2.2 Catalysts of cathodes Improving the performance of M−N batteries necessitates the incorporation of appropriate electrocatalysts with high activity. These catalysts help mitigate the overpotential associated with various electroreduction reactions in batteries, thereby accelerating the otherwise sluggish reaction kinetics. Until now, endeavors have been undertaken to enhance the activity of half-reaction electrocatalysts in M−N batteries. Precious metal based electrocatalysts (such as Pd, Pt and Au) usually exhibit excellent activity in electroreduction reactions [63]. Nevertheless, the industrial advancement of M−N batteries is hindered by the scarcity and expense of precious metals. As a result, there has been considerable interest in electrocatalysts without precious metals (like Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) and metal-free electrocatalysts that can match the activity of catalysts containing precious metals. This is attributable to various strategies that govern the composition, coordination environment, and structure [64]. Beyond solely focusing on the electrode's inherent activity, the judicious management of the cathode surface in M−N batteries holds pivotal significance. The reaction substrate properties in organic/aqueous metal-gas batteries and aqueous metal-liquid batteries differ, with one involving ions and the other gases. Therefore, distinct catalyst surfaces should be devised for each reaction system. Especially in organic/aqueous M−N batteries where gas participates at the cathode, as seen in systems like organic/aqueous metal-N2, aqueous metal-NO and metal-NO2 batteries, the catalytic activity of the electrocatalytic cathode half-reaction apart from the inherent reaction kinetics, the local environment at the triple-phase interfaces involving the solid catalyst, liquid electrolyte, and gaseous reactant or product during reactions can significantly influence the electrochemical performance. Factors such as mass transport, electron conduction, and accessibility of active sites are crucial for the electrocatalytic processes and can be highly sensitive to the microenvironment [65]. Moreover, the real operating conditions of the electrocatalyst in M−N batteries substantially differ from those of the cathode semi-reaction. Consequently, the slow transfer of charges and gas diffusion limitations at the cathode may result in the incomplete utilization of active sites [66]. Hence, it is imperative to methodically engineer the electrode surface structure, optimize the three-phase interface, and mitigate side reactions between the electrocatalyst and electrolyte. This approach accelerates specific reaction kinetics, enhancing the overall performance of M−N batteries. Furthermore, considering the intricate reaction environment in M−N batteries, it becomes crucial to address the stability and durability of the electrocatalyst. To mitigate electrocatalyst degradation, surface blockage, and interference from competing reactions, the preservation of the catalyst's active site and emphasis should be placed on the distinct structural features and surface characteristics. Certainly, from an economic standpoint, a pivotal aspect in enhancing the industrial application potential of electrocatalysts is cost reduction. It is imperative to consider not only the expenses related to raw materials but also those associated with the preparation process, transportation, and environmental considerations. 2.3 Considerations for reaction parameters Apart from the internal composition's influence on battery performance, external factors play a significant role in shaping the functionality of the battery. Hence, meticulous adjustment of the reaction parameters within the discussed M−N battery system is of utmost importance. By optimizing the electrolyte flow, electrolyte pH, chemical raw material concentration and reaction temperature, the ideal operating conditions for laboratory research and practical applications can be obtained. Furthermore, a filtration unit is essential to capture the dissolved chemical NH3 and purify the electrolytes utilized. Moreover, when fine-tuning reaction parameters, it's crucial to consider not just varying M−N battery configurations, but also diverse industrial demands, energy origins, and product preferences. 3 Metal-N2/NO x redox batteries 3.1 Organic metal-N2 batteries Ammonia holds particular significance as a key ingredient in numerous food products and fertilizers. Additionally, ammonia serves as a direct or indirect component in the composition of various pharmaceutical drugs. Given its extensive array of applications, ammonia stands as one of the most widely produced inorganic compounds on a global scale [67,68]. However, the Haber-Bosch method is presently the primary technique used for producing ammonia. Nonetheless, it requires high temperature and pressure settings and consumes significant quantities of coal and natural gas, leading to substantial carbon dioxide emissions [69–73]. Therefore, an environmentally friendly strategy is urgently required for NH3 production. Electrocatalytic NRR presents a promising alternative to the Haber-Bosch process, offering lower energy requirements, improved energy efficiency, and enhanced production safety [74]. We can integrate the NRR with M−N batteries to simultaneously generate energy and fix nitrogen, then produce NH3 (Table 2 ). 3.1.1 Reaction mechanism of organic Li/Na/Al-N2 batteries Due to their high theoretical energy and excellent reversibility, Li-N2 batteries (LNBs) have become extensively researched within the domain of electrochemical nitrogen fixation. Consequently, LNBs facilitate a simultaneous N2/Li3N cycle, positioning them as a potentially groundbreaking technology for future energy storage systems. A rechargeable LNB featuring a carbon cloth (CC) cathode and an electrolyte based on ethers was reported [75]. During discharge, solid Li3N is produced, which then fully converts back into the original feed reactants as the discharge product. The reversible reactions involved in the discharge–charge cycle can be summarized as follows. Anode reaction: 6Li → 6Li+ + 6e– Cathode reaction: N2 + 6Li+ + 6e– → 2Li3N Overall reaction: 6Li + N2 → 2Li3N A faradic efficiency (FE) of up to 59% for N2 fixation was reported in a N2 fixation battery system assembled (Fig. 3 a–d). Given that the catalysts play a crucial role in enhancing N2 fixation efficiency, Ru-CC and ZrO2-CC composite cathodes were explored, and remarkably, the lithium-nitrogen batteries assembled with catalysts exhibited higher faradic efficiency (FE) compared to pristine CC cathodes. Drawing upon the analogous chemical and structural characteristics shared by Li and Na, a systematic exploration of organic Na-N2 batteries has been undertaken. A proof of concept has been established to engineer reversible and rechargeable Na-N2 batteries (NNBs) through the utilization of α-MnO2 nanowires (NWs)/CC as the cathode catalyst. Notably, the charge–discharge reactions mirror those observed in lithium-nitrogen batteries (LNBs) [76]. This system demonstrates remarkable performance, exhibiting a reversible capacity of 600 mA h g−1 at 50 mA g−1. It sustains approximately 80 cycles with a controlled capacity of 400 mA h g−1 at discharge terminal voltage below 1.6 V, while achieving a high actual specific energy density based on total active materials (approximately 4900 W h kg−1) at a current density of 100 mA g−1. Moreover, it achieves a good efficiency of nitrogen fixation (∼26%). These impressive results are primarily attributed to the unique channel structure, high conductivity, and exceptional catalytic activity, as revealed by in-situ environmental transmission electron microscopy investigations. Although Li/Na-N2 batteries show potential for various applications, the considerable Gibbs free energy involved in the formation of Li3N or Na3N highlights the need for catalysts and the presence of significant electrochemical polarizations. Given the higher Gibbs free energy for the AlN formation reaction (−287 kJ mol−1), there is an exploration into organic rechargeable Al-N2 batteries. Initially, a rechargeable ANB focusing on N2 fixation was developed, employing graphene/Pd as the cathode catalyst along with an aprotic ionic liquid electrolyte. Below elucidates the reaction mechanism [77]. Anode reaction: 2Al + 14AlCl4 – → 8Al2Cl7 – + 6e– Cathode reaction: N2 + 8Al2Cl7 – + 6e– → 14AlCl4 – + 2AlN Overall reaction: 2Al + N2 → 2AlN In this setup, the creation and breakdown of the cathodic AlN product during cycling are essential for ensuring the battery's ability to recharge and maintain its cycle life (Fig. 3e). Remarkably, the battery demonstrates outstanding capabilities in fixing N2, boasting an impressive faradaic efficiency (FE) of 51.2%, surpassing performance seen in other systems. Additionally, in organic metal-N2 batteries, the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer forms on the negative electrode surface through the reaction of inorganic electrolyte substances with the negative electrode material. This layer functions as a solid electrolyte, enabling efficient metal ion conductivity while insulating electrons. It effectively prevents solvent molecules from co-intercalating into the electrode material, thereby enhancing electrode cycle performance and lifespan. Thus, optimizing the SEI layer enhances overall battery performance [74–76]. In the realm of organic metal-N2 batteries, the sluggish reaction kinetics arising from the formation and dissolution of soluble and insulating discharge byproducts lead to heightened overpotential and decreased energy efficiency during cycling. Furthermore, the degradation of discharge capacity in metal-air batteries is exacerbated by the decomposition of organic electrolytes and the generation of side products, particularly under elevated current densities [79–82]. 3.1.2 Electrochemical performance of current organic metal-N2 batteries Due to the limited activity and durability of the cathode catalyst, the electrochemical performance of organic metal-N2 batteries does not meet optimal standards. Consequently, a range of strategies is imperative to enhance the overall electrochemical performance of these batteries. The graphene cathode catalyst and 1 M LiClO4 in TEGDME served as the electrolyte, demonstrating a respectable cut-off discharge capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1 after 50 cycles with the LNB. Analysis uncovered the existence of both the discharge product Li3N and isolated LiOH on the cathode after undergoing a 50-hour deep discharge procedure [83]. Simultaneously, a decrease in the N element content on the cathode both pre and post cycle was also observed by the research team, indicating the possibility of more intricate discharge products during cycling. Through continued research efforts, the challenges in the application of organic Li-N2 batteries have been systematically addressed, leading to substantial improvements in their electrochemical performance. Nonetheless, controversies persist regarding their electrochemical reversibility and the intricacies of their reaction mechanisms. A heterostructure composed of Ru/Mo2C, synthesized on N-doped carbon nanotubes (NCNTs) through atomic layer deposition, was investigated as a cathode catalyst for N2 utilization and electrochemical energy storage in Li-N2 battery systems. The battery utilizing the Ru/Mo2C-NCNTs cathode showcases a specific capacity exceeding 8500 mA h g−1 and maintains stability over 50 discharge/charge cycles, with a consistently low overpotential of 2.4 V at a current density of 100 mA g−1 [83]. Additionally, a reversible and rechargeable Li-N2 battery was assembled using non-precious SnO2-dispersed N-doped carbon nanosheets (N-CNS)/CC cathode catalysts, and the previously employed LiCF3SO3 and LiClO4 electrolytes were replaced with LiTFSI. Notably, the Li-N2 battery demonstrated full reversibility, providing a high discharge capacity of around 500 mA h g−1 (0.25 mA h) even under extreme current rates of 1000 mA g−1 after 100 consecutive cycles. This remarkable performance can be attributed to the sturdy N2 adsorption/desorption properties of the SnO2 catalyst, the excellent conductivity of NCNS and CC, and the homogeneous pore distribution within the cathode catalysts (Fig. 3f and g). 3.2 Aqueous metal-N2 redox batteries 3.2.1 Reaction mechanism and primary/rechargeable metal-N2 battery The solvent in the electrolyte of aqueous M−N batteries (Table 3 ) replaces traditional organic solvents with water, providing distinct benefits: it is environmentally friendly, safe and cost-effective. Building upon this notion, research indicates that the surface mass transport properties of catalysts are crucial factors influencing the electrocatalytic selectivity of NRR over the competing HER in aqueous environments, particularly on metallic copper substrates. Thus, a primary Zn-N2 battery was assembled as a new application for the NRR [85]. By adjusting the thickness of Cu nanoparticles to a monolayer, a significant NRR FE of 33% was attained. The specific reaction pathway is outlined as follows (Fig. 4 a–d). Anode: Zn + 2OH– →ZnO + H2O + 2e– Cathode: N2 + 6H2O + 6e– → 2NH3 + 6OH– Overall reaction: 3Zn + N2 + 3H2O → NH3 + 3ZnO However, this non-rechargeable Zn-N2 battery is primarily tailored for applications like artificial nitrogen fixation and energy generation, serving as a primary power source. Ren et al. proposed an aqueous rechargeable Zn-N2 battery with active bifunctional NRR-OER catalysts (Fig. 4e) [86]. They constructed an aqueous rechargeable Zn-N2 battery by pairing bifunctional cobalt phosphate nanocrystals-loaded heteroatoms-doped carbon nanosheets (CoPi/NPCS) as the cathode electrocatalyst with a commercial Zn plate serving as the anode, employing KOH electrolyte. This CoPi/NPCS-catalyzed Zn-N2 battery achieved a high yield rate of N2 to NH3 at 14.7 μg h−1 mgcat. –1 and a FE of 16.35% at 0.6 V vs. Zn2+/Zn, while demonstrating a peak power density of 0.49 mW cm−2 and an energy density of 147.6 mW h gzn –1 (Fig. 4f and g). Apart from Zn, Al serves as another invaluable catalyst, showcasing outstanding properties. Accordingly, a proposed solution involves an aqueous Al-N2 battery featuring cathode electrocatalysts comprised of hollow molybdenum phosphate microspheres (Fig. 4h) [87]. Below elucidates the reaction mechanism. Anode: 2Al + 8OH– → 2AlO2 – + 4H2O + 6e– Cathode: N2 + 6H2O + 6e– → 2NH3 + 6OH– Overall reaction: 2Al + N2 + 2H2O + 2OH– → 2NH3 + 2AlO2 – Benefiting from the advantageous active components present in molybdenum phosphates and the increased exposure of active sites, the fabricated MoPi/HSNPC catalyst demonstrates remarkable performance in nitrogen reduction reactions (NRR) within alkaline electrolytes (Fig. 4i and g). The catalyst demonstrated a peak NH3 yield rate of 18.66 μg h−1 mgcat. –1 at −0.2 V vs. RHE, boasting a Faradaic efficiency of 9.04%. This performance level compares favorably with recently revealed non-precious catalysts for NRR. Moreover, it exhibited impressive long-term cycle stability, signaling a promising avenue for aqueous Al-N2 battery research. Electrochemical NRR is emerging as an eco-friendly approach to ammonia synthesis, leveraging room temperature conditions and readily available atmospheric nitrogen and water as feedstocks. Nonetheless, the substantial bond energy of N≡N bonds (941 kJ mol−1) and their limited solubility in water hinder efficient ammonia production, compounded by the competing HER, which compromises NRR performance. Hence, there's a pressing need for the development of highly efficient catalysts to address these challenges. 3.2.2 Strategies on improving electrochemical performance for the aqueous metal-N2 batteries Drawing from advancements in bifunctional catalysts and innovations in electrolyte and anode materials for aqueous metal-N2 batteries, future development trajectories and enhancement strategies are suggested for such batteries, focusing on the following aspects: Defect engineering offers a pragmatic approach to enhance electrocatalytic reduction efficiency by adeptly modulating the electronic characteristics and surface configuration of catalysts. Notably, vacancy defects within the crystal lattice have surfaced as a promising avenue for fine-tuning electrode materials [88–90]. An active and stable electrocatalyst for NRR by plasma-etched Ti2O3 with oxygen vacancies (OV-Ti2O3) was reported (Fig. 4k) [91]. An aqueous Zn-N2 battery equipped with the OV-Ti2O3 cathode demonstrated a power density of 1.02 mW cm−2 alongside an NH3 yield of 4.3 µg h−1 mgcat. –1 upon assembly. In addition, introducing heteroatom doping can effectively modulate the electronic configuration of the catalyst, thereby enhancing its catalytic activity. Drawing from the material's inherent structure, the introduction of various foreign atoms both metallic (e.g., Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) and non-metallic (e.g., N, O, C, B, P, S) can redistribute electron and spin densities within the catalyst. This adjustment facilitates the fine-tuning of reaction intermediate energetics at precise locations [92,93]. Leveraging this concept, a novel structure termed ultrathin N.S-codoped carbon matrix-embedded vanadium nitride nanodots (VN@NSC) was engineered. This innovative design showcased notable attributes including durable stability, elevated NH3 yield, and insensitivity to pH fluctuations during the electrochemical ammonia synthesis process [35]. Moreover, VN@NSC served as the active N2 cathode within an assembled aqueous Zn-N2 battery. This configuration facilitated both NH3 synthesis, with an average yield of 0.172 μg h−1 cm−2, and concurrent electricity generation, yielding a power density of 16.42 μW cm−2. Such performance underscores its considerable promise for real-world applications. Manipulating surface morphology offers a pathway to enhance the NRR performance of catalysts by modifying their physical and chemical characteristics. The catalytic performance of a material is profoundly affected by its specific surface area and microstructure. Consequently, adjusting the catalyst to a nanostructured form offers benefits such as increased surface area, enhanced mass transfer rates, and improved reaction stability. Inspired by the breathing process of mammalian alveoli, a shell-engineering approach was devised to craft iron-doped titanium dioxide hollow nanospheres (FeHTNs) abundant in oxygen vacancies, tailored for NRRs (Fig. 4l) [94]. The distinctive hollow configuration and porous shell of FeHTNs expedite N2 delivery into a structure akin to “alveoli”, extending contact time with the inner surface of electrocatalysts. This prolonged interaction accelerates NRR kinetics, thereby promoting efficient ammonia synthesis. When Fe1.0HTNs were employed as the N2 cathode in assembling aqueous Zn-N2 batteries, they demonstrated dual functionality: ammonia production (with an average NH3 yield of 0.172 mg h−1 cm−2) and electricity generation (yielding a power density of 16.42 mW cm−2). This dual capability presents an intriguing potential for practical utilization. In the same way, 2D transition metal compounds present promising candidates as electrocatalysts owing to their ultra-thin layered structure, expansive specific surface area, dense distribution of surface active sites, superior electrochemical characteristics, and facile interface transmission, thus facilitating shorter diffusion pathways [95,96]. An exfoliated FePS3 nanosheet, characterized by a porous structure and abundant sulfur vacancies (Vs-FePS3 NSs), was created through a combination of electrochemical exfoliation and hydrogenation processes (Fig. 4m) [97]. Due to their abundant sulfur vacancies and distinctive 2D structure, featuring a thickness of approximately 15 nm and lateral dimensions around 500 nm, Vs-FePS3 NSs exhibit remarkable electrochemical activity in NRR. This is evidenced by a high Faradaic efficiency of 12.36% at −0.20 V and an ammonia yield rate of 3.88 μg h−1 cm−2 at −0.25 V versus the reversible hydrogen electrode under acidic conditions. Furthermore, when employed as the cathode in a Zn-N2 battery configuration, Vs-FePS3 NSs demonstrate a notable power density of 2.6 mW cm−2 (Fig. 4n). 3.3 Aqueous Zn-NO x redox batteries 3.3.1 Reaction mechanism of aqueous Zn-NO x batteries NO poses a substantial threat to human health, primarily affecting the respiratory tract. This is due to its high oxidative nature [100–103], rendering it more amenable to reduction than the comparatively inert, non-polar N2. Hence, the development of aqueous Zn-NO batteries hold promise for achieving simultaneous NO abatement and NH3 production (Table 4 ). It is reported that an aqueous Zn-NO battery assembled with MoS2 nanosheet on graphite felt (MoS2/GF) acts as a 3D electrocatalyst for NO to NH3 conversion [101]. Below elucidates the reaction mechanism. Anode: Zn + 2OH– → ZnO + H2O + 2e– Cathode: NO + 5H+ + 5e– → NH3 + H2O Overall reaction: 5ZnO + 2NO + 3H2O → 5ZnO + 2NH3 The calculations analysis indicates that the positively charged Mo-edge site enhances the adsorption and activation of NO via a receiving-donation mechanism. However, this mechanism discourages proton binding and N–N bond coupling. In an acidic electrolyte, MoS2/GF achieves a peak Faradaic efficiency of 76.6% and yields a substantial NH3 production rate of up to 99.6 mmol cm–2 h−1. A power density of 1.04 mW cm−2 and an NH3 yield of 411.8 μg h−1 mgcat. –1 can be obtained in the aqueous Zn-NO battery when using this MoS2 nanosheet-loaded carbon as the cathode. NO demonstrates relatively subdued reactivity, yet it readily oxidizes into NO2 upon exposure to the atmosphere—an entity recognized for its potent corrosive and toxic attributes. This conversion significantly contributes to pollution in water, soil, and the atmosphere [104–107]. Hence, an imperative exists to devise a strategy that can concurrently alleviate the detrimental effects of nitrogen dioxide accumulation while generating value-added chemicals or electricity. The electrocatalytic transformation of NO2 into valuable compounds offers a hopeful strategy to mitigate disturbances caused by human activities in the worldwide nitrogen cycle. An envisioned electrochemical setup comprises an aqueous Zn-NO2 battery design, incorporating a cathode coated with a nano-NiO catalyst, a Zn foil anode, and an electrolyte consisting of a ZnCl2 aqueous solution [40]. Below elucidates the reaction mechanism. Anode: Zn → Zn2+ + 2e– Cathode: 2NO2 + 2e– → 2NO2 – Overall reaction: Zn + 2NO2 → Zn (NO2)2 The electrolyte effectively captures NO2, converting it into NO2 – and ultimately into valuable NH3, while also generating electrical power. Remarkably, pouch cells (2.4 A h) have achieved a high cell-level energy density of 553.2 W h kg–1 cell/1589.6 W h L–1 cell. And an electrochemical Haber-Bosch reactor was constructed, self-powered by the Zn-NO2 batteries to convert NO2 to NO2 – and further to NH3. The self-sustaining system can generate an NH3 yield of 4 mM h−1, maintaining a consistent output current density of 2.1 mA cm−2 at 3.0 V. This demonstrates the potential to harness residual kinetic energy from exhaust gas to facilitate valuable NH3 synthesis. 3.3.2 Strategies on improving electrochemical performance for the aqueous metal-NO x batteries Prudent nanoarray structure design imparts distinctive surface effects to the catalyst material, facilitating ease of size control. An efficient NORR electrocatalyst for the selective hydrogenation of NO to NH3 was devised, utilizing a Ni2P nanosheet array on carbon paper (Ni2P/CP) as the substrate [108]. In a 0.1 M HCl solution, Ni2P/CP demonstrates significant NH3 production at a rate of 33.47 mmol h−1 cm−2, coupled with a commendable faradaic efficiency of 76.9% at 0.2 V vs. the reversible hydrogen electrode. Moreover, it exhibits exceptional durability under operational circumstances. The aqueous Zn-NO battery assembled with Ni2P/CP delivers a discharge power density of 1.53 mW cm−2 and an NH3 yield of 62.05 mg h−1 mgcat. –1 (Fig. 5 a and b). Theoretical computations indicate that the Ni2P (111) surface facilitates NO adsorption and activation through an “acceptance-donation” mechanism, with the hydrogenation of *NO to *NOH identified as the potential-determining step (Fig. 5c and d). Furthermore, theoretical investigations were conducted to explore the competition of the HER and other byproducts. The findings substantiate the superior selectivity of the NO to NH3 conversion process. Additionally, the research team has made significant contributions in developing efficient catalysts, when used as the cathode of the aqueous Zn-NO battery, a high NH3 production selectivity can be demonstrated by these catalysts [109–116]. Furthermore, designing electrocatalytic NORR catalysts involves the effective strategy of constructing atomically dispersed catalysts with distinctive atomic structures and electronic properties [118]. Ce single atoms were incorporated onto nitrogen-doped hollow carbon spheres (Ce-SA/NHCS), a deliberate design choice [119]. Theoretical analysis suggests that the atomically scattered Co-N4 active component efficiently suppresses competing HER while simultaneously boosting the hydrogenation of reaction intermediates. As a result, Ce-SA/NHCS exhibits a FE of 91% and an NH3 yield rate of 1023 μg h−1 mgcat. –1 at −0.7 V vs. RHE. These findings surpass those of Ce nanoclusters (Ce-NC/NHCS), despite lower Ce contents, and are comparable to leading reported results. Notably, in a Zn-NO battery with Ce-SA/NHCS as the cathodic catalyst, a peak power density of 3.4 mW cm−2 and an impressive NH3 yield rate of 309 μg h−1 mgcat. –1 were achieved, marking a significant advancement over previous Zn-N2 batteries. This investigation expands the application of single-atom catalysts (SACs) for highly efficient NORR to NH3 conversion and NO removal. The team also prepared NORR electrocatalysts for nickel–iron layered double hydroxide nanosheet arrays [120] and nitrogen-doped carbon nanosheets encapsulating MoC nanocrystals [121], both of which showed excellent NORR electrocatalytic performance in Zn-NO aqueous solution batteries. Lattice regulation presents a novel approach to augmenting the properties of catalyst materials. An arrangement of cobalt nanosheets in a hexagonal-close-packed (hcp-Co) configuration was developed to efficiently transform NO into NH3 (Fig. 5e) [122]. The hcp phase of Co demonstrates superior performance, with a high NH3 yield of 439.50 μmol cm–2 h−1 and a Faraday efficiency of 72.58%. This outperforms the face-centered cubic phase (fcc-Co) of the Co nanosheet and surpasses the majority of previously reported results (Fig. 5f–h). By combining density functional theory calculations with NO temperature-programmed desorption experiments, the improved catalytic performance of hcp-Co in the NORR is due to its unique electron configurations and the facilitation of proton transfer. What's even more remarkable, the Zn-NO batteries shows a high open-circuit voltage of 2.06 VZn, an NH3 yield of 247.80 μg h−1 mgcat. –1 and a power density of 4.66 mW cm−2, when using the hcp-Co as the cathode. The batteries mentioned above are part of the metal-gas series batteries, including aqueous/organic metal-N2, aqueous metal-NO and aqueous metal-NO2 batteries. Unlike traditional organic metal-N2 batteries, the electrolyte solvent in aqueous metal-N2 and metal-NO x batteries substitutes the typical organic solvent with water, providing notable benefits such as environmental friendliness, safety, and cost-effectiveness. Additionally, our research and comparisons have consistently shown that aqueous metal-nitrogen oxide batteries outperform aqueous/organic metal-N2 batteries in terms of performance. 4 Aqueous Zn-NO x – redox batteries 4.1 Reaction mechanism of aqueous Zn-NO x – batteries Due to its higher reduction potential, NO2 – proves to be well-suited for constructing electrochemical systems capable of simultaneously generating ammonia and energy [123,124]. Therefore, NO2 –RR has broad application prospects in aqueous Zn-NO2 – batteries. A Zn-NO2 – battery was engineered, employing carbon-doped cobalt oxide (C/Co3O4) hollow nanotubes assembled from nanoparticles as the cathode. This configuration facilitates the concurrent degradation of NO2 –, NH3 production, and electricity generation [58]. Below elucidates the reaction mechanism. Anode: 3Zn → 3Zn2+ + 6e– Cathode: NO2 – + 6H2O + 6e– → NH4OH + 7OH– Overall reaction: 3Zn + NO2 – + 6H2O → 3Zn2+ + NH4OH + 7OH– The introduction of interstitial C dopants induces a local electric field, enhancing charge transfer and reducing the energy barrier of the rate-determining step (*N + e– + H2O − *NH + OH), thereby promoting the NO2 –RR process. Consequently, C/Co3O4 demonstrates a nearly 100% FE for NH3 production across a wide potential window from 0.1 to 0.6 V versus a reversible hydrogen electrode. The Zn-NO2 – battery, when assembled, achieves a power density of 6.03 mW cm−2 and a peak NH3 FE of 95.1%. Nitrates are pervasive environmental pollutants, commonly found in various forms, including gaseous water, surface water, groundwater, as well as within the bodies of animals and plants. Exceeding the recommended levels of nitrate in the human body can lead to severe and potentially fatal health consequences [125]. Hence, there is a pressing need to transform harmful nitrates into NH3, a compound beneficial to us, by means of nitrate electroreduction. By incorporating NO3 –RR into aqueous Zn-NO3 – batteries, we can simultaneously address nitrate pollution and generate electricity, offering a comprehensive solution to this environmental issue (Table 5 ). The conception and realization of a Zn-nitrate battery system coincided with the unveiling of a remarkably effective Pd-doped TiO2 nanoarray electrode tailored for NH3 synthesis via the NO3 –RR (Fig. 6 a and b). By introducing Pd, the catalyst exhibits reduced adsorption capacities towards intermediates, culminating in unprecedented NH3 yields of 1.12 mg cm–2 h−1, an impressive NH3 Faradaic efficiency of 92.1%, and exceptional nitrate conversion rates of 99.6%. In conjunction, the assembled aqueous Zn-NO3 – battery, integrated with Pd-TiO2, achieves a power density of 0.87 mW cm−2, coupled with a Faradaic efficiency of 81.3% (Fig. 6c). A recently documented aqueous Zn-NO3 – battery featured a design comprising Zn foil serving as the anode and nickel foam hosting Ru nanoparticles acting as the cathode. Below elucidates the reaction mechanism [126]. Anode: 4Zn + 8OH– → 4ZnO + 4H2O + 8e– Cathode: NO3 – + 7H2O + 8e– → NH4OH + 9OH– Overall: 4Zn + NO3 – + 3H2O → NH4OH + OH– Due to the creation of a Ru/Ni hydroxide hybrid, there is a notable enhancement in the reaction rate to 384 mmol h−1 mgRu –1, coupled with an impressive Faradaic efficiency of 97% ± 2% at −0.6 VRHE. Throughout ammonia generation, this Zn-NO3 – battery can sustain an impressive maximum power density of 51.5 mW cm−2 and 23.3 mW cm−2, while maintaining an exceptionally high Faradaic efficiency of 97% ± 4% at 40 mA cm−2 even during prolonged testing. 4.2 Strategies on improving electrochemical performance for the aqueous metal-NO x – batteries The two catalysts mentioned above are both precious metals (Pd and Ru), and the high cost and low durability of precious metal electrocatalysts hinder their practical application. Therefore, transition metals and their derivatives represent viable substitutes for mitigating these constraints. Since there are still some problems in the electrocatalytic activity of transition metal-based catalysts, various strategies for optimizing transition metal-based catalysts have been proposed [126,127]. A compact membranous Co nanomaterial (DM-Co) was fabricated on a copper substrate via a combination of chemical and electrochemical deposition techniques, showcasing superb electrocatalytic capabilities for selectively converting NO3 – to NH4 + and facilitating low overpotential alkaline OER [38]. The cathode catalyst facilitates both the reduction of NO3 – to NH4 + and the oxidation of OH– to O2 through pathways with low overpotentials, influencing the overall battery reaction: NO3 – + 3H2O → NH4 + + 2OH– + 2O2. The resulting electrochemical cell exhibits over 90% selectivity for NO– to NH4 +, achieves a power density exceeding 25 mW cm−2, and sustains stable cycling for 35 h at 12.5 mA cm−2. Additionally, this Zn-NO3 – battery can be powered by a photovoltaic cell, achieving a solar-to-NH3 efficiency of up to 19.5%. This is due to the intrinsic tendency of metallic Cu-based materials to manifest a comparatively diminished capacity for supplying atomic H*. In contrast to homogeneous catalysts, heterogeneous catalysts offer the advantage of multiple active centers and effective morphological control. Thus, a new and straightforward approach involving O2/Ar plasma oxidation followed by electroreduction was devised to produce a metastable phase of copper [36]. The metastable form of copper exhibits enhanced performance in NITRR compared to the conventional phase, boasting remarkable NH4 + selectivity (97.8%) and Faradaic efficiency (99.8%). The enhanced selectivity and Faradaic efficiency are likely due to the adjustment of the d band center towards the Fermi level in the metastable phase of copper, coupled with the strong adsorption of H, which aids in converting NO2/NO* to NOOH/NOH (Fig. 6d and e). When evaluated as the cathode, a high power density (7.56mWcm−2) and an NH4 + yield (76 µmolh−1 cm−2) are achieved. Moreover, the eight-electron transfer process in NO3 −RR stands as a crucial factor influencing its reactivity. Addressing the sluggish 8-electron transfer kinetics in NO3 –RR, a Cu nanowire array was utilized as a proficient electrocatalyst for nitrate reduction. This arrangement splits the NO3 –RR process into two phases using a [2 + 6]– electron pathway, reducing the kinetic barrier (Fig. 6f–h) [128,129]. When transition metals and their compounds are used as the cathode of aqueous Zn-NO3 – batteries, single-atom doped catalysts, structural engineering, interface engineering and defect engineering strategies can effectively optimize the activity and overall performance of electrocatalytic NO3 –RR [131–137]. Recently, single-atom doped catalysts have emerged as promising electrode materials in a variety of energy storage and conversion systems, owing to their unique features. As an illustration, an effective catalyst for NO3 –RR, Iron-doped nickel phosphide (Fe/Ni2P), was developed [134]. The NH3 Faradaic efficiency of the Fe/Ni2P catalyst is remarkable at 94.3%, with nitrate conversion efficiency nearly reaching 100% at −0.4 V vs. RHE. The Fe/Ni2P-integrated aqueous Zn-NO3 – battery achieves a notable power density of 3.25 mW cm−2 and a substantial Faradaic efficiency of 95.0% for NH3 production. Furthermore, a novel hybrid nanoarray of NiCoBDC@HsGDY with a multifunctional interface was proposed. This involves surface engineering of bimetallic Ni/Co-MOFs (NiCoBDC) with hydrogen-substituted graphdiyne (HsGDY) (Fig. 6i) [133]. By employing interface engineering, a fraction of electrons is transferred from Ni2+ to the coordination-unsaturated Co2+ sites on the surface of NiCoBDC. This dual effect not only enhances the reduction of *NO3 on Co2+ but also activates the hydrolytic dissociation to form *H on Ni2+. Furthermore, the conformally coated HsGDY facilitates the simultaneous accumulation of electrons and NO3 – ions at the NiCoBDC-HsGDY interface. This arrangement effectively promotes the reduction of *NO3 to *H on Ni2+ and·H2O on Co2+, transitioning from deoxidation to hydrogenation processes (Fig. 6j). Consequently, the NiCoBDC@HsGDY nanoarray exhibits substantial NH3 yield rates, maintaining a Faradaic efficiency exceeding 90% across broad potential and pH ranges. When integrated into an aqueous Zn-NO3 – battery configuration, it attains a notable power density of 3.66 mW cm−2, indicating promising prospects within the realm of aqueous Zn-based batteries. Recent reports highlight that the combined effects of hydrogen-bond interactions and hydrogen spillover significantly enhance NO3RR performance. A highly effective catalyst for NO3RR, sub-nm RuO x clusters anchored on a Pd metallene (RuO x /Pd), has been reported [141]. Operando spectroscopic characterizations, coupled with theoretical computations, reveal how the synergy between RuO x and Pd enhances NO3RR energetics via mechanisms involving hydrogen spillover and hydrogen-bond interactions. In detail, RuO x activates NO3 – to form intermediates, while Pd dissociates H2O to generate *H, which migrates spontaneously to the RuO x /Pd interface via a hydrogen spillover process. Further hydrogen-bond interactions between the spillovered *H and intermediates facilitate its desorption from the RuO x /Pd interface and its participation in intermediate hydrogenation, thereby enhancing the activity of RuO x /Pd for converting NO3 – to NH3. Based on the comprehensive analysis provided above, it is evident that aqueous metal-NO x – batteries consistently demonstrate superior performance compared to metal-NO x /N2 batteries across a range of performance indicators. These indicators include efficiency, NH3 yield rates and stability, making aqueous metal-NO x – batteries the preferred choice for power generation and storage applications due to their remarkable performance attributes. 5 Current problems with metal-N redox batteries Basically, metal-N species batteries, including aqueous/organic metal-N2, aqueous metal-NO, aqueous metal-NO2, aqueous metal-NO3 – and aqueous metal-NO2 – batteries can hold promise for converting seemingly useless or detrimental gases into valuable NH3 while simultaneously generating electricity. Nevertheless, in the context of these M−N batteries, the hydrogen evolution reaction always takes precedence over the NRR/NORR/NO3 –RR and NO2 –RR, resulting in a poor Faradic efficiency and low NH3 yield. The presence of the unwanted HER significantly reduces the conversion efficiency in M−N series batteries. In the above report, we summarize the efforts of many current researchers to improve the selectivity of these electro-reduction reactions. They designed highly efficient cathode catalysts for inhibiting HER to achieve higher voltages output, power densities, NH3 yield rates and FEs. Nonetheless, despite the development of relatively efficient cathode catalysts for catalyzing the reaction, the selectivity of the HER process still remains high. Consequently, there is an ongoing need to enhance the yield of NH3 production and establish efficient product separation facilities. Moreover, in the realm of power generation, the reported power density from these endeavors is still considerably below the desired ideal standards. Therefore, subsequent research efforts should prioritize enhancing the selectivity of these reactions while also augmenting the power density for improved power generation capabilities. In addition to exploring intrinsic catalytically active sites, catalytic processes and reaction mechanisms should be investigated using in-situ characterization methods and theoretical calculations. Despite the preparation of various electrocatalysts with excellent catalytic performance in recent years, there remains an insufficient in-depth understanding of their catalytic mechanisms. Advanced characterization methods, including X-ray absorption spectroscopy, electron paramagnetic resonance, and in-situ Raman spectroscopy, have been employed to investigate complex reaction mechanisms. However, further study is needed to explore the relationship between intrinsic activity, geometric and coordination structures, surface modulation of active sites, and their configuration during catalysis. Besides grappling with the competitive reaction challenges in M−N batteries, their development remains nascent, primarily confined to laboratory settings without widespread industrial application. In laboratory settings, the ideal experimental conditions, including electrolyte pH, gas flow rate, and electrode surface area are pivotal for conducting standardized tests and evaluating electrocatalyst designs effectively. Moreover, integrating battery configurations with operando characterization technology allows for comprehensive performance analysis under conditions mimicking real-world operation, offering valuable insights for catalyst refinement. Furthermore, addressing product separation concerns, particularly concerning the solubility of chemical byproducts, necessitates the incorporation of filtration mechanisms within battery setups to facilitate product collection and electrolyte purification. Further creative configurations for batteries are also required. Moreover, it is crucial to attain bifunctional electrocatalytic performance to facilitate the rechargeable processes of the battery. The mismatch between multi-element and multi-charge transfer rate requires the rational design of coupling active sites with high intrinsic activity at the atomic level. To comprehensively gauge the effectiveness of these strategies, computational studies emerge as indispensable tools for gaining in-depth insights into atomic and interface mechanisms. Incorporating computational methods into research efforts within this field is essential. Utilizing catalyst descriptors along with machine learning techniques facilitates catalyst screening, streamlining the design process. This approach provides a dependable interpretation of structure–activity relationships for the developed electrocatalysts. This streamlined approach holds the promise of circumventing the laborious trial-and-error practices commonly tied to traditional experimental methods. Furthermore, in the process of selecting an electrocatalyst for practical application, it is imperative to factor in the overall cost involved in catalyst development. This cost encompasses not only the expenses related to raw materials but also those tied to the preparation process, transportation, and its environmental footprint. As we chart the course for future research endeavors, a strong emphasis should be placed on prioritizing materials derived from earth's abundant resources, employing straightforward preparation techniques, sourcing materials locally, and minimizing adverse environmental impacts. By taking all these considerations into account, the integration of M−N batteries into everyday life and industrial production can be accelerated, thereby expanding their application prospects. 6 Conclusions and outlook This review delves into the latest advancements within M−N series battery technology, which have the capability to perform multiple electroreduction reactions at the cathode. This enables concurrent power generation alongside valuable chemical production, wastewater treatment, or product purification. We firstly provide a comprehensive and detailed review to describe batteries and cathode discharging reactions, including NRR, NORR, NO3 –RR and NO2 –RR. We comprehensively delve into the cathodes and anodes of M−N batteries. Subsequently, we meticulously explore the recent advancements in the design of electrocatalysts across various M−N batteries. The discussion covers recent research advancements, focusing on strategies to improve the activity, selectivity, and stability of electrocatalysts, as well as their practical suitability for battery applications. Finally, we present an insightful analysis of the challenges and opportunities confronting current M−N bifunctional catalyst batteries, offering valuable guidance for future research endeavors. The actual performance of batteries also relies on factors such as the electrode catalyst and battery configuration. Specifically concerning electricity generation, organic/aqueous metal-N2, aqueous metal-NO, metal-NO3 –, metal-NO2 – and metal-NO2 batteries achieve a peak power density ranging from 0 to 92 mW cm−2. and aqueous metal-NO x – batteries consistently exhibit superior performance compared to metal-NO x /N2 batteries (Fig. 7 ). Hence, within the M−N series battery, enhancing the overall battery performance is achievable through modifications in the substrate of nitrogen species. Our review underscores the viability of this concept, paving the way for promising avenues. Consequently, future scientific research endeavors can delve into the exploration of additional N species for their participation in the M−N series battery systems. Moreover, batteries employing noble metal-based catalysts typically demonstrate enhanced overall performance. Nevertheless, the widespread use of precious metal catalysts is hindered by their high cost and limited availability. Consequently, in pursuit of cost-effective alternatives, non-precious metal-based materials emerge as promising substitutes. The development of non-precious metal-based catalysts holds significant importance in achieving both cost reduction and broader applicability. In addition, the reactant sources of M−N batteries are considered to be zero cost, which is conducive to practical applications. Besides, removing the N source from the air and producing ammonia can create additional value. Future research endeavors should extensively investigate value-added metal-redox bicatalyst batteries, focusing on achieving high selectivity. Moreover, to enhance versatility and boost potential for industrialization, it is imperative to explore additional electroreduction reactions within configurations of metal-redox dual catalyst batteries, beyond the presently promising options. Given the progress of M−N batteries to date, as well as the challenges and opportunities for their future development, we are optimistic about the development potential in this area. The conception of a novel approach to value-added power generation holds significant promise for advancing the emergence of a renewable economy, contributing to environmental preservation and energy production. This review aims to offer insightful guidance for the advancement of M−N battery systems, potentially catalyzing further developments in this domain. coredata.dc:description: Ammonia plays a crucial role in contemporary society, impacting medicine, agriculture, and the chemical industry. The conventional industrial synthesis of NH3 through the Haber-Bosch technique, carried out under severe reaction conditions, leads to substantial energy consumption and environmental pollution. It is thus imperative for NH3 synthesis methods to be investigated under more favorable conditions. Synthesis of ammonia by electrocatalysis can effectively reduce the environmental damage and other urgent problems, which is a promising solution. Metal-nitrogen series batteries (M−N batteries), such as metal-nitrogen gas batteries, metal-nitrogen oxide batteries and metal-oxynitride batteries have been regarded recently as an exemplar of concurrent NH3 synthesis and energy production.Nonetheless, the large-scale application of these batteries is still limited by numerous challenges are currently existing in building high-efficiency M−N batteries, including poor Faradic efficiency and low NH3 yield. Therefore, a comprehensive overview of M−N batteries is offered, specifically focusing on advanced strategies for designing highly efficient cathode catalysts in anticipation of future developments. The metal anodes, cathodic electro-reduction reactions, and design principles are encompassed in the discussion, offering detailed insights to enhance understanding. Mechanisms, feasibility analyses, technoeconomic assessments, device combinations, and comparative evaluations are delved into in the review, contributing to a thorough comprehension of diverse systems and their application potential. Perspectives and opportunities for future research directions are also delineated.
